function_call.name: get_risks
function_call.arguments: {"risks":[{"Description":"Potential difference between lab conditions and real-world scenarios for metal surface exposure. This could affect the effectiveness of copper in mitigating the spread of the virus.","Impact":"Misleading information on the efficacy of copper surfaces in real-world settings.","Mitigation":"Conduct further studies and testing of copper surfaces under real-world conditions to verify its efficacy in mitigating the spread of the virus.","Technologies":"Real-world simulation testing, environmental exposure chambers, field testing equipment.","People":"General public, facility managers, public health officials, researchers.","Owner":"Research institutions, public health organizations, facility management companies."},{"Description":"Uncertainty regarding the effectiveness of copper coatings on 3D-printed surfaces in inactivating the COVID-19 virus.","Impact":"Lack of clarity on the antiviral properties of 3D-printed copper coatings could lead to ineffective mitigation strategies.","Mitigation":"Conduct in-depth research to understand the mechanisms of COVID-19 virus inactivation on 3D-printed copper coatings.","Technologies":"Advanced microscopy, virus inactivation assays, surface chemistry analysis.","People":"Researchers, manufacturers of 3D-printed components, public health officials.","Owner":"Research institutions, manufacturers, public health organizations."},{"Description":"Varied efficacy of copper surfaces based on copper content and form (native, nanoparticle) raises concerns about the uniformity of antiviral properties across different copper materials.","Impact":"Confusion about which type of copper material is most effective in inactivating viruses, leading to inconsistent mitigation efforts.","Mitigation":"Standardize testing procedures to evaluate the antiviral properties of different types of copper, and communicate clear guidelines on the recommended copper materials for virus mitigation.","Technologies":"Material characterization techniques, antiviral efficacy assays, standardized testing protocols.","People":"Manufacturers, public health officials, researchers, facility managers.","Owner":"Industry standardization bodies, public health organizations, research institutions."}]}
